text.p: These are the main stories in Latvian newspapers on Thursday. Prepared for Reuters by the Co-operation Fund. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Latvia's Transit Business Association held a closed meeting, attended by Prime Minister Andris Shkele.
- Latvian Foreign Minister Valdis Birkavs views the recent remarks of German counterpart Klaus Kinkel on the Baltics as positive.
- A 33-year old Latvian gave birth to triplets, each of them weighing 1.5 kg. The parents received greetings from Shkele.
- Amendments, freeing the land market, to the law on the privatisation of land in urban areas have been approved by the government's economic and finance committee.

- In 1996, inflation in Latvia was 13.1 percent, the state statistics committee said. In December, consumer prices rose by 0.6 percent. Last year, inflation in Estonia reached 14.8 percent and 13.1 percent in Lithuania.
- Police in the port city of Ventspils arrested a transport police officer for the rape and strangulation of a 12-year old schoolgirl.

- The general prosecutor's office will not initiate legal action against the former chief of Latvia's security police, Raimond Rozhkalns, aftre allegations he took part in refugee smuggling from Russia.

- The cabinet approved amendments to the law on excise tax, which provides for a gradual introduction of excise tax on beer and the reduction of excise on strong wines. By 2001, beer excise on drinks with 5.5 percent to seven percent of alcohol will rise to 12 lats per hectolitre.
- Central bank chief Einar Repshe called on Latvia's banks to increse lending and widen their client base, saying that otherwise they would be ousted from the market by foreign competitors.
